facts.text: This is Civil Appellate Jurisdiction C.A. No. 15 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 15 of 1972. Appeal by Special Leave from the,

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated December 16, 1971 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 431 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the, judgment and order dated December 16, 1971 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 431 of 1970.

facts.text: Appellant challenges the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland refusing to set aside the order of the Assam Government dated June 16, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the appellant challenges the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland in refusing to set aside the order of the Assam Government dated June 16, 1970 granting a companytract to Respondent No. 5

facts.text: Assam Government order dated June 16, 1970 granted contract to Respondent No. 5 for wholesale supply of country spirit to Tinsukia and North Lakhimpur warehouses for three years from July 1, 1970 to June 30, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: order of the Assam Government dated June 16, 1970 granting a companytract to Respondent No. 5 for wholesale supply of companyntry spirit to Tinsukia and North Lakhimpur warehouses for three years from July 1, 1970 to June 30, 1973.

facts.text: Appellant is a Public Limited Company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Public Limited Company. Under a companytract entered into between it and the Government of Assam,

facts.text: Appellant had exclusive privilege under contract with Government of Assam to supply country spirit to two warehouses in District of Lakhimpur from July 1, 1967 to March 3, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Under a companytract entered into between it and the Government of Assam, it had the exclusive privilege of supplying companyntry spirit to the two warehouses in the District of Lakhimpur for the period from July 1, 1967 to March 3, 1970.

facts.text: Commissioner of Excise, Assam invited tenders in sealed covers for privilege of supplying country spirit to retail vendors in Upper Assam area comprising District of Lakhimpur and Sibsagar including Mikir Sub-Division for three years commencing April 1, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime before that companytract came to an end, the Commissioner of Excise, Assam invited tenders in sealed companyers for the privilege of supplying the, companyntry spirit to, retail vendors in the Upper Assam area companyprising of the District of Lakhimpur and Sibsagar including Mikir Sub-Division of the United Mikir and North Cachar Hills for the period of three years companymencing from April 1, 1970.

facts.text: Notification issued by Commissioner stated that preference will be given to manufacturers of the spirit.

anchor.surface_text: In the numberification issued by the Commissioner, it was stated that preference will be given to the manufacturers, of the spirit.

facts.text: Appellant, 5th respondent and several others submitted tenders followed by necessary licences.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the tender numberice,  the appellant, the 5th respondent and several others submitted tenders for the grant of the companytract in question followed up by necessary licences.

facts.text: Appellant offered to supply spirit at 74 P. per London proof litre.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant offered to supply the spirit at 74 P. per London proof litre. Respondent No. 5 quoted the price at 95 P. per London proof litre.

facts.text: Respondent No. 5 quoted 95 P. per London proof litre.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 5 quoted the price at 95 P. per London proof litre. Another tenderer namely Rampur Distillery and Chemicals Company Ltd. offered the lowest rate of 60 P. per London proof litre.

facts.text: Rampur Distillery and Chemicals Co. Ltd. offered 60 P. per London proof litre but tender was defective and rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Another tenderer namely Rampur Distillery and Chemicals Company Ltd. offered the lowest rate of 60 P. per London proof litre. The tender of Rampur Distillery and Chemicals Co. Ltd., was found to be defective and therefore it was rejected.

facts.text: Government was not satisfied with any of the tenders.

anchor.surface_text: The Government was number satisfied with any of the tenders. Thereafter by a letter dated February 28, 1970,

facts.text: Government by letter dated February 28, 1970 called upon all tenderers to intimate if willing to reduce rate and to what extent, replies by March 10, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter by a letter dated February 28, 1970, it called upon all the tenderers to intimate to the Government whether they were willing to reduce their rate and if so, to what extent. They were required to send their replies by March 10, 1970.

facts.text: None of the tenderers except 5th respondent was willing to reduce the rate quoted.

anchor.surface_text: None of the tenderers excepting the 5th respondent was willing to reduce the rate quoted by them.

facts.text: Managing Director of Respondent No. 5 by letter dated March 4, 1970 informed Government willing to reduce rate, left it to Government to fix reasonable rate, agreed to accept.

anchor.surface_text: The Managing Director of Respondent No. 5, by his letter dated March 4, 1970 informed the Government that his companycern was willing to reduce the rate and he left it to the Government to fix any rate which it companysidered reasonable. He agreed to accept the rate fixed by the Government.

facts.text: Government reduced rate of Respondent No. 5 to 74 P. per London proof litre and accepted its tender.

anchor.surface_text: The Government reduced the rate fixed by Respondent No. 5 to 74 P. per London proof litre and accepted its tender.

facts.text: Appellant moved High Court of Assam and Nagaland under Art. 226 to quash Government order granting contract to 5th respondent and direct concerned respondents not to give effect to impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this decision, the appellant moved the High Court of Assam and Nagaland under Art. 226 of the Constitution to quash the Government Order granting the companytract to the 5th respondent and for issuing a direction to the companycerned respondents number to give effect to the impugned order.

facts.text: High Court rejected the application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected that application. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: No allegation of mala fides made against the Government.

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, it is necessary to mention that numberallegation of mala fides is made against the Government.

facts.text: Government granted contract to 5th respondent at the rate quoted by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that ultimately it granted the companytract to the 5th respondent at the very rate quoted by the appellant.

facts.text: Tender of Rampur Distillery was rejected because defective.

anchor.surface_text: The tender of Rampur Distillery and Chemicals Co. Ltd., was found to be defective and therefore it was rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we are unable to accept any of the companytentions advanced on behalf of the appellant. Hence this appeal fails and the same is dismissed.

facts.text: No order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: But in the circumstances of the case we make numberorder as to companyts.

under Art. 226 of the Constitution to quash the Government Order granting the contract to the 5th respondent and for issuing a direction to the concerned respondents not to give effect to the impugned order.
Appeal by Special Leave from the, judgment and order dated December 16, 1971 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 431 of 1970.
In this appeal by special leave the appellant challenges the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland in refusing to set aside the order

issues.text: whether the impugned order was made in violation of any statutory provisions

anchor.surface_text: The only question that we have to consider in this appeal is whether the impugned order was made in violation of any statutory provisions.

issues.text: whether the Government has stated that none of the tenders were satisfactory as required under Rule 93

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the appellant that the impugned order cannot be sustained firstly because the Government has nowhere stated that the tenders made were not acceptable to it on the ground that none of them, on due consideration, appear to be satisfactory,

issues.text: whether under Rule 93 the Government could enter into negotiations with the tenderers

anchor.surface_text: It was next said that Rule 93 prohibits the Government to negotiate with any of the tenderers. We are unable to read that rule in that way. That rule does not prohibit any negotiations with the tenderers.

issues.text: whether the Government can give preference to manufacturers of spirit over other tenderers

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie there is nothing wrong in giving preference to the manufacturers. ... The Government does not require any special power for preferring one class of sellers to others so long as the classification made by it is based on rational grounds.

issues.text: whether the principles of natural justice required the Government to give opportunity to other tenderers to reduce their rates before granting the contract

anchor.surface_text: It was faintly argued that before concluding its contract with the 5th respondent, the Government should have given opportunity to the other tenderers to reduce the rates quoted by them. This contention is clearly a misunderstanding of the principles of natural justice.

arguments.claim: Absent rules, Government can exercise s.19 power in manner most advantageous to State without infringing constitutional guarantees

anchor.surface_text: This provision undoubtedly confers on the Government very wide powers in the matter of granting exclusive privilege... holdings.text: The impugned order was not made in violation of any statutory provisions

holdings.text: From the facts stated earlier, it is clear that the Government considered the tenders to be unsatisfactory and hence unacceptable

anchor.surface_text: Neither of these contentions are sound. From the facts stated earlier, it is clear that the Government considered the tenders to be unsatisfactory and hence unacceptable. That is clear from its letter to the tenderers asking them to reduce the price quoted.

holdings.text: That rule does not prohibit any negotiations with the tenderers

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read that rule in that way. That rule does not prohibit any negotiations with the tenderers. But on the other hand, it authorises the Government to negotiate with persons who have not tendered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of Rule 93 authorizes negotiation with non-tenderers and lacks prohibition on tenderers; falls back on wide s.19 powers

holdings.text: The Government does not require any special power for preferring one class of sellers to others so long as the classification made by it is based on rational grounds

anchor.surface_text: The Government does not require any special power for preferring one class of sellers to others so long as the classification made by it is based on rational grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preference to manufacturers ensures supply guarantee; rational classification under Art.14 principles
